description: After days of mounting protests and escalating unrest, Nikola Petrak privately struggles with his decision. Conversations with a former Council contact highlight fears that if order collapses, chaos will follow.
Nikola Petrak authorizes the Directorate to assume emergency control, granting them override of Council command networks. This critical decision paves the way for martial law.

The Directorate quickly suspends the Council, announces martial order, and imposes strict curfews. BCI penalties are threatened for disobedience, but within hours, resistance emerges as neighborhoods reject digital surveillance.

In response to harsh control, residents organize analog communication, sabotage BCI sensors, and refuse digital services. Citywide cooperation deteriorates as large groups withdraw from the system, making it difficult for the Directorate to enforce compliance.

Amid prolonged breakdowns in BCI scoring and city services, grassroots movements demand abolition of the BCI system. Mutual aid networks replace official services in many neighborhoods; tensions peak as citizens openly defy the Directorate's authority.
